overall_score_comment: Pretty solid, though someone needs to gently inform Billie that healthy relationships don't usually require casket-carrying commitments.
the_roast:
Listen, I appreciate the dedication here, but 'til I'm in the casket you carry' is giving me less 'romantic devotion' and more 'potential lawsuit from a chiropractor.' We've gone from love song to ergonomic workplace hazard in one line. Also, can we talk about how Billie speedruns through every death metaphor known to humanity? Grave, rot, casket, turning blue, light leaving eyes—girl saved some for the rest of us songwriters, please! This reads like someone's first day with a rhyming dictionary's 'mortality' section.

The 'birds of a feather' chorus is genuinely sweet until you remember she just spent the whole verse threatening to haunt someone from beyond the grave. It's like planning a cute picnic right after discussing your joint burial plots. 'Can't change the weather, might not be forever'—finally, a reasonable sentiment! Oh wait, never mind, she immediately follows with 'but if it's forever, it's even better.' We were SO CLOSE to having healthy boundaries there.

'You're so full of shit' followed by 'tell me it's a bit' is the most relatable part of this entire song, honestly. At least we've moved from death pacts to normal relationship banter. And 'I knew you in another life'? Of course you did. Because one lifetime of intense commitment wasn't enough—we had to throw in reincarnation too. This isn't just co-dependency; it's multi-dimensional co-dependency.

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Turning romance into a weekend mortuary seminar
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory couples therapy and a subscription to 'Healthy Boundaries Monthly'

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Extremely concerning medical advice disguised as devotion
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Someone please check on this person's emergency contacts

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Whiplash-inducing tonal shift from 'I'll love you forever' to 'you're full of it'
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Attendance at a seminar on emotional consistency

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Can't change the weather, might not be forever / But if it's forever, it's even better
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Contradicting herself within the same breath
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must choose one commitment level and stick with it for at least 30 seconds

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a metaphor for how we're all trapped in the eternal cycle of Spotify playlists, destined to hear the same songs until we physically can't anymore. The 'casket you carry' is obviously our phone with its dead battery, and 'turning blue' is what happens when we forget to charge it overnight.
final_verdict: A hauntingly catchy song that makes eternal devotion sound both romantic and like it might require a restraining order. Sweet melody, though someone should maybe check in on Billie's concept of proportional emotional responses.
title: Birds of a Feather
